issues.title: error code

issues.body: AP10: Section 4.3 - GM refuses the join request with 4.xx if the client_cred passed in was not in the correct format.

issues.title: Editorial
issues.author: fpalombini
issues.body: AP4: In Section 6, clarify in the third bullet on asymmetric PoP.

issues.title: PoP of signature key
issues.author: fpalombini
issues.body: AP5: In Section 6, proof-of-possession of the client’s private key, e.g. by signing a nonce returned by the GM in the response to the Token post.

issues.title: Editorial
issues.author: fpalombini
issues.body: AP6: In Section 6, third bullet point, clarify about ensuring that any signature algorithm parameters that might exist are going to be checked and enforced.

issues.title: addition about rekeying
issues.author: fpalombini
issues.body: AP7: Specify that when using the OSCORE profile between group member and GM, the joining nodes need to have both client and server roles. This means configuring their keying material accordingly. In particular, the group member’s recipient context need to contain a replay window).

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
It's not needed if the token authorizes the client to be only monitor in all the groups covered in the token.

Is it worth addressing and implementing this optimization? Or rather to just return a kdcnonce even in such a case, even thoug that joining node is not going to use the received kdcnonce to build a signature challenge?

comments.author: jimsch
comments.body: I don't know if it is worth it or not, that is a question that could be left to the implementer if it the field is optional rather than required.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
Following the major restructuring of ace-key-groupcomm, the two TOCs are now more aligned from a high-level point of view.

Some differences remain, but IMO they yield a convenient reading experience for ace-key-groupcomm-oscore , which inherits the KDC interface and presents the execution of operations grouped as "thematic clusters" in chronological order (e.g., group joining, retrieve/update public keys, retrieve other info, group leaving).

issues.title: Remove redundancy of key type capabilities
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body: This applies to 'sign_info' and 'ecdh_info' in the response to the Token POST, as well as to 'key:cs_params' in the Joining Response.

issues.title: Parameter Extensibility for Future COSE Algorithms
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In Section 3.3.1 of ace-key-groupcomm, the definition of 'sign_info_entry' adheres with the existing COSE algorithm. However, future COSE algorithms may admit zero or more than one capabilities, beyond Key Type. That would need to be reflected with additional, corresponding arrays following 'sign_key_parameters'. At the same time, REQ4 and REQ5 leave the details about specified properties to application profiles. The same applies also to the specific content of 'key' in the Joining Response, whose details are also left to application profiles (REQ10).

Considering exactly Group OSCORE, this can be addressed in ace-key-groupcomm-oscore as done in core-oscore-groupcomm, where Appendix H defines a future-friendly template for the same kind of extension, there with respect to parameters in the OSCORE Security Context and to elements in the external_aad.
   
Following the same rationale, the 'sign_*_parameters' arrays after 'sign_parameters' would be as many as the elements of 'sign_parameters', i.e. one for each capability of the signature algorithm.
   
The same thing can be done for 'ecdh_info_entry' , i.e. the 'ecdh_*_parameters' arrays after 'ecdh_parameters' would be as many as the elements of 'ecdh_parameters', i.e. one for each capability of the ECDH algorithm.

The same logic applies to corresponding parameters in the 'key' element of responses from ace-group/GROUPNAME (e.g. the Joining Response) and from ace-group/GROUPNAME/nodes/NODENAME, 'cs_params', 'cs_key_params', 'ecdh_params' and 'ecdh_key_params'.

Like in core-oscore-groupcomm, applying this template to any of today's existing COSE algorithms results in the exact parameters and formats detailed in the document body.

issues.title: Default value of the Pairwise Key Agreement Algorithm
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In Section 14.3 "Pairwise Mode", the text should be updated to reflect that the default value of the Pairwise Key Agreement Algorithm is actually implied by the HKDF Algorithm used in the group.

See also Section 2.1.9 of draft-ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm : https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm-18#name-pairwise-key-agreement-algo

issues.title: Renaming of parameters
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Consistently with the recent updates in draft-ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm, the following parameters should be renamed as below:

* "Group Encryption Key" becomes "Signature Encryption Key"

* 'group_enc_key' becomes 'sign_enc_key'

* "Signature Encryption Algorithm" becomes "Group Encryption Algorithm"

* 'sign_enc_alg' becomes 'gp_enc_alg'

issues.title: Authentication Credential Format in the OSCORE Common Context
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
draft-ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm has introduced a new parameter Authentication Credential Format in the Common Context of the Group OSCORE Security Context.

Therefore, the parameter 'cred_fmt' included, e.g., in the Join Response should be said to be used for filling the new parameter Authentication Credential Format in the Common Context.

issues.title: Align with the resolution of issue #146 in -ace-key-groupcomm
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
After [1] has been addressed in draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm ...

In Section 6.3 "Send the Join Response", between the two bullet points about 'creds' and 'peer_identifiers', add text consistent with the resolution of [1].

In particular, 'peer_roles' MUST be present if 'creds' is present, with the possible exception for the case where all the authentication credentials specified in 'cred' somehow specify the roles that the corresponding group members have in the group. In such a case, 'peer_roles' MAY be omitted even if 'creds' is present.

A typical example is the case where the authentication credentials in the group are CWTs or CCSs, and they somehow specify the roles that the group member is authorized to have in the group.

There is no additional expectation on the Group Manager to check that the authentication credentials include such information when uploaded by the joining nodes. That is, the decision on not including the 'peer_roles' parameter can be taken on a per Join Response basis, depending on the specific set of authentication credentials specified in the 'cred' parameter of that Join Response.

[1] https://github.com/ace-wg/ace-key-groupcomm/issues/146

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
The issue #146 of -ace-key-groupcomm [1] has been resolved with quite general text that already captures all the points above. Therefore, no additions should be needed in this document, which silently inherits what is defined in -ace-key-groupcomm

[1] https://github.com/ace-wg/ace-key-groupcomm/issues/146

issues.title: Clarifications on the maximum size of the OSCORE Sender ID
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In Section 6.3 "Send the Join Response", after the paragraph:

> Consistently with Section 3.2.1 of [I-D.ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm], the Group Manager MUST assign an OSCORE Sender ID that has not been used in the OSCORE group since the latest time when the current Gid value was assigned to the group.

Add more text (see an example below) based on the recent addition to draft-ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm on the maximum length of the Sender IDs.

> The maximum length of a Sender ID in bytes equals L minus 6, where L is determined as follows.
> 
> * If only one among the Group Encryption Algorithm and the AEAD Algorithm is set, L is the AEAD nonce length for the set algorithm.
> 
> * If both the Group Encryption Algorithm and the AEAD Algorithm are set, L is the smallest AEAD nonce length among those of the two algorithms.

Later in Section 9.2 "Request to Change Individual Keying Material" and due to the same reason, point to the new text added to Section 6.3, after the sentence:

> The Group Manager determines and assigns a new OSCORE Sender ID for that group member, and replies with a Key Renewal Response formatted as defined in Section 4.8.2 of [I-D.ietf-ace-key-groupcomm].

issues.title: Parameters left "unset"
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body: Based on the parlance recently introduced in draft-ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm, Section 6.3 "Send the Join Response" should point out that the joining node leaves the parameters for the encryption algorithms "unset" in the Group OSCORE Security Context, if the Group Manager does not specify those parameters in the Join Response.

issues.title: Fix the URI of a sub-resource at the Group Manager
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In Section 8.4 "Admitted Methods", the Table in Figure 2 should be fixed as follows

OLD: ace-group/GROUPNAME/nodes/NODENAME/pub-key

NEW: ace-group/GROUPNAME/nodes/NODENAME/cred

issues.title: Fix response code from the Group Manager
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In Section 9.2 "Request to Change Individual Keying Material"

Within the bullet point 1, the error code should not be 4.03 (Forbidden), but rather 4.00 (Bad Request), consistently with Section 4.1.2 of draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm

issues.title: Clarify meaning of 'cred_fmt'
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Section 5.3.1 "'ecdh_info' Parameter" of version -16 says:

`The fifth element 'cred_fmt' is a CBOR integer indicating the format of authentication credentials used in the OSCORE group identified by 'gname'. It takes value from the "Label" column of the "COSE Header Parameters" registry [COSE.Header.Parameters] (REQ6). Acceptable values denote a format that MUST explicitly provide the public key as well as a comprehensive set of information related to the public key algorithm. This information includes, e.g., the used elliptic curve (when applicable). The same considerations and guidelines for the 'cred_fmt' element of 'sign_info' apply (see Section 5.3).`

It should better say:

The fifth element 'cred_fmt' is a CBOR integer indicating the format of authentication credentials used in the OSCORE group identified by 'gname'. It takes value from the "Label" column of the "COSE Header Parameters" registry [COSE.Header.Parameters] (REQ6)**, with some of those values also indicating the type of container to use for exchanging the authentication credentials with the Group Manager (e.g., a chain or bag of certificates)**. Acceptable values denote a format that MUST explicitly provide the public key as well as a comprehensive set of information related to the public key algorithm. This information includes, e.g., the used elliptic curve (when applicable). The same considerations and guidelines for the 'cred_fmt' element of 'sign_info' apply (see Section 5.3).

---

Section 5.3.2 "''kdc_dh_creds' Parameter" of version -16 says:

`The second element 'cred_fmt' is a CBOR integer indicating the format of authentication credentials used in the OSCORE group identified by 'gname'. It takes value from the "Label" column of the "COSE Header Parameters" registry [COSE.Header.Parameters] (REQ6). Acceptable values denote a format that MUST explicitly provide the public key as well as a comprehensive set of information related to the public key algorithm. This information includes, e.g., the used elliptic curve (when applicable). The same considerations and guidelines for the 'cred_fmt' element of 'sign_info' apply (see Section 5.3).`

It should better say:

The second element 'cred_fmt' is a CBOR integer indicating the format of authentication credentials used in the OSCORE group identified by 'gname'. It takes value from the "Label" column of the "COSE Header Parameters" registry [COSE.Header.Parameters] (REQ6)**, with some of those values also indicating the type of container to use for exchanging the authentication credentials with the Group Manager (e.g., a chain or bag of certificates)**. Acceptable values denote a format that MUST explicitly provide the public key as well as a comprehensive set of information related to the public key algorithm. This information includes, e.g., the used elliptic curve (when applicable). The same considerations and guidelines for the 'cred_fmt' element of 'sign_info' apply (see Section 5.3).

---

Section 6.3 "Send the Join Response" of version -16 says:

`The 'cred_fmt' parameter specifies the format of authentication credentials used in the OSCORE group. This parameter MUST be present and it takes value from the "Label" column of the "COSE Header Parameters" registry [COSE.Header.Parameters] (REQ6). Consistently with Section 2.3 of [I-D.ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm], acceptable values denote a format that MUST explicitly provide the public key as well as a comprehensive set of information related to the public key algorithm. This information includes, e.g., the used elliptic curve (when applicable).`

It should better say:

The 'cred_fmt' parameter specifies the format of authentication credentials used in the OSCORE group. This parameter MUST be present and it takes value from the "Label" column of the "COSE Header Parameters" registry [COSE.Header.Parameters] (REQ6)**, with some of those values also indicating the type of container to use for exchanging the authentication credentials with the Group Manager (e.g., a chain or bag of certificates)**. Consistently with Section 2.3 of [I-D.ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm], acceptable values denote a format that MUST explicitly provide the public key as well as a comprehensive set of information related to the public key algorithm. This information includes, e.g., the used elliptic curve (when applicable).

---

Appendix A.1 "Mandatory-to-Address Requirements" of version -16 says:

`REQ6 - Specify the acceptable formats for authentication credentials and, if used, the acceptable values for 'cred_fmt': acceptable formats explicitly provide the public key as well as the comprehensive set of information related to the public key algorithm (see Section 5.3 and Section 6.3). Consistent acceptable values for 'cred_fmt' are taken from the "Label" column of the "COSE Header Parameters" registry [COSE.Header.Parameters].`

It should better say:

REQ6 - Specify the acceptable formats for authentication credentials and, if used, the acceptable values for 'cred_fmt': acceptable formats explicitly provide the public key as well as the comprehensive set of information related to the public key algorithm (see Section 5.3 and Section 6.3). Consistent acceptable values for 'cred_fmt' are taken from the "Label" column of the "COSE Header Parameters" registry [COSE.Header.Parameters]**, with some of those values also indicating the type of container to use for exchanging the authentication credentials with the Group Manager (e.g., a chain or bag of certificates).**

issues.title: Revise future-ready generalization of 'ecdh_info_entry'
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Appendix B.1 "Format of 'ecdh_info_entry'" of version -16 says:

> The i-th array following 'ecdh_parameters', i.e., 'ecdh_capab_i' (i = 0, ..., N-1), is the array of COSE capabilities for the algorithm capability specified in 'ecdh_parameters'[i].

It should say:

> The i-th array following 'ecdh_parameters', i.e., 'ecdh_capab_i' (i = 1, ..., N), is the array of COSE capabilities for the algorithm capability specified in 'ecdh_parameters'[i-1], i.e., alg_capab_i.

EDIT: Following the revised CDDL definition of the generalized, future-ready format of 'ecdh_info_entry' (see issue #65), this issue has become more about updating and clarifying the description of each information element.

The new text before the CDDL definition should read as follows.

> The format of each 'ecdh_info_entry' (see Section 5.3 and Section 5.3.1) is generalized as follows.
> 
> * 'ecdh_parameters' includes N >= 0 elements, each of which is a COSE capability of the ECDH algorithm indicated in 'ecdh_alg'.
> 
>    In particular, 'ecdh_parameters' has the same format and value of the COSE capabilities array for the ECDH algorithm indicated in 'ecdh_alg', as specified for that algorithm in the 'Capabilities' column of the "COSE Algorithms" registry {{COSE.Algorithms}}.
> 
> * 'ecdh_key_parameters' is replaced by N elements 'ecdh_capab', each of which is a CBOR array.
> 
>    The i-th 'ecdh_capab' array (i = 0, ..., N-1) is the array of COSE capabilities for the algorithm capability specified in 'ecdh_parameters'\[i\].
> 
>    In particular, each 'ecdh_capab' array has the same format and value of the COSE capabilities array for the algorithm capability specified in 'ecdh_parameters'\[i\].
> 
>    Such a COSE capabilities array is currently defined for the algorithm capability COSE key type, in the "Capabilities" column of the "COSE Key Types" registry {{COSE.Key.Types}}.

issues.title: Better name for the TLS exporter label
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
With reference to version -16, the TLS exporter label defined in Section 16.7 and used in Section 6.1.1 can be renamed as follows, to be more general.

OLD
> EXPORTER-ACE-Sign-Challenge-coap-group-oscore-app

NEW
> EXPORTER-ACE-Pop-Input-coap-group-oscore-app

That is, the PoP evidence is not necessarily a signature, hence the PoP input is not necessarily a signature challenge.

issues.title: Clarify alternative computing of N_S Challenge when DTLS is used
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In Section 6.1.1 of version -16, point 2 refers to the TLS exporter method from Section 7.5 of RFC 8446. However, that method is actually applicable only if DTLS 1.3 is used.

To correctly distinguish between the case of DTLS 1.2 and of DTLS 1.3, the text in Section 6.1.1 can be updated as follows:

OLD

> 2. If the provisioning of the Access Token to the Group Manager has relied on the DTLS profile of ACE [RFC9202], and the Access Token was specified:
> 
>    * in the "psk_identity" field of the ClientKeyExchange message when using DTLS 1.2 [RFC6347]; or
> 
>    * in the "identity" field of a PskIdentity within the PreSharedKeyExtension of the ClientHello message when using DTLS 1.3 [RFC9147],
> 
>    then N_S is an exporter value computed as defined in Section 7.5 of [RFC8446]. Specifically, N_S is exported from the DTLS session between the joining node and the Group Manager, using an empty 'context_value', 32 bytes as 'key_length', and the exporter label "EXPORTER-ACE-Sign-Challenge-coap-group-oscore-app" defined in Section 16.7 of this document.

NEW:

> 2. If the provisioning of the Access Token to the Group Manager has relied on the DTLS profile of ACE [RFC9202], and the Access Token was specified in the "psk_identity" field of the ClientKeyExchange message when using DTLS 1.2 [RFC6347], then N_S is an exporter value computed as defined in Section 4 of [RFC 5705].
> 
>    Specifically, N_S is exported from the DTLS session between the joining node and the Group Manager, using an empty context value (i.e., a context value of zero-length), 32 as length value in bytes, and the exporter label "EXPORTER-ACE-Pop-Input-coap-group-oscore-app" defined in Section 16.7 of this document.
> 
> 3. If the provisioning of the Access Token to the Group Manager has relied on the DTLS profile of ACE [RFC9202], and the Access Token was specified in the "identity" field of a PskIdentity within the PreSharedKeyExtension of the ClientHello message when using DTLS 1.3 [RFC9147], then N_S is an exporter value computed as defined in Section 7.5 of [RFC8446].
> 
>    Specifically, N_S is exported from the DTLS session between the joining node and the Group Manager, using an empty 'context_value' (i.e., a 'context_value' of zero length), 32 as 'key_length' in bytes, and the exporter label "EXPORTER-ACE-Sign-Challenge-coap-group-oscore-app" defined in Section 16.7 of this document.


The new text uses the new name for the TLS exporter label as suggested in issue https://github.com/ace-wg/ace-key-groupcomm-oscore/issues/63

issues.title: Fix the CDDL definition of 'ecdh_info_entry'
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In version -16, Section 5.3.1 "'ecdh_info' Parameter" includes the definition

OLD
```
ecdh_info_entry =
[
  id : gname / [ + gname ],
  ecdh_alg : int / tstr,
  ecdh_parameters : [ any ],
  ecdh_key_parameters : [ any ],
  cred_fmt : int
]
```

NEW
```
[
  id : gname / [ + gname ],
  ecdh_alg : int / tstr,
  ecdh_parameters : [ any ],
  ecdh_key_parameters : [ + parameter : any ],
  cred_fmt : int
]
```

Also, Appendix B.1 "Format of 'ecdh_info_entry'" includes the definition

OLD
```
ecdh_info_entry =
[
  id : gname / [ + gname ],
  ecdh_alg : int / tstr,
  ecdh_parameters : [ alg_capab_1 : any,
                      alg_capab_2 : any,
                      ...,
                      alg_capab_N : any],
  ecdh_capab_1 : [ any ],
  ecdh_capab_2 : [ any ],
  ...,
  ecdh_capab_N : [ any ],
  cred_fmt : int / null
]

gname = tstr
```

NEW
```
ecdh_info_entry =
[
  id : gname / [ + gname ],
  ecdh_alg : int / tstr,
  ecdh_parameters : [ * ecdh_capab : any ],
  * ecdh_capab : [ * capab : any ],
  cred_fmt : int / null
]

gname = tstr
```

issues.title: Reference to X.509 certificates
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body: The correct reference for X.509 certificates is not RFC 7925, but rather RFC 5280.

issues.title: Relation between cred_fmt and "Authentication Credential Format"
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body: When a node receives a response from the group-membership resource or the node resource at the Group Manager, the node has to take the value of the 'cred_fmt' parameter in the 'key' parameter, and accordingly populate the new "Authentication Credential Format" parameter in the Common Context of the Group OSCORE Security Context.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Addresed by https://github.com/ace-wg/ace-key-groupcomm-oscore/commit/e5fb5e1df33b05b83a11761b8dc2c5cdb3a69bcf

issues.title: Consistent use of the leading slash in URI paths
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body: Ensure a consistent use of the leading slash "/" when mentioning resources at the Group Manager.

issues.title: Consistency with the mandatory use of 'cnonce'
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Revise to ensure consistency about the mandatory use of the 'cnonce' parameter from draft-ietf-key-groupcomm-17.

With reference to version -16 of this document, the following changes are needed.

Section 4 "Authentication Credentials"

OLD
> ..., the Group Manager silently ignores that parameter, as well as the related parameters 'cnonce' and 'client_cred_verify'.

NEW
> ..., the Group Manager silently ignores that parameter, as well as the related parameter 'client_cred_verify'.


Section 6.3 "Send the Join Response"

OLD
> The 'kdc_cred_verify' parameter MUST be present, specifying the proof-of-possession (PoP) evidence computed by the Group Manager. The PoP evidence is computed over the nonce N_KDC, which is specified in the 'kdc_nonce' parameter and taken as PoP input. The PoP evidence is computed as defined below (REQ21).

NEW
> The 'kdc_cred_verify' parameter MUST be present, specifying the proof-of-possession (PoP) evidence computed by the Group Manager. The PoP evidence is computed as defined below (REQ21).


Section 12 "ACE Groupcomm Parameters"

OLD
> When the conditional parameters defined in Section 8 of [I-D.ietf-ace-key-groupcomm] are used with this application profile, a Client must, should or may support them as specified below (REQ30).
>
> * 'client_cred', 'cnonce', 'client_cred_verify'. A Client that has an own authentication credential to use in a group MUST support these parameters.

NEW
> When the conditional parameters defined in Section 8 of [I-D.ietf-ace-key-groupcomm] are used with this application profile, a Client must, should or may support them as specified below (REQ30).
>
> * 'client_cred' and 'client_cred_verify'. A Client that has an own authentication credential to use in a group MUST support these parameters.

issues.title: New FETCH handler for /ace-group/GROUPNAME/kdc-cred
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
This new handler is intended for a signature verifier that will have to use a FETCH request instead of a GET request to access the resource.

Due to the additional client-side nonce introduced in draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm-17, the signature verifier has to provide the Group Manager with a nonce, which the Group Manager uses as part of the Proof-of-Possession input when preparing the response.

Hence the need for a FETCH request, whose payload specifies a nonce generated by the requester, by means of the same parameter 'cnonce' already defined and used in other messages.

The response to return is just like the response from the GET handler defined in draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm-17, with the difference that the value to use as N_C for the PoP input is instead the value specified in the payload of the FETCH request.

A FETCH request to this resource is not valid if sent by a group member, and it is valid only if received by a node authorized to be external signature verifier, just like it is the case already for the resource /ace-group/GROUPNAME/verif-data .

issues.title: Point to RFC 9237 in the CDDL definition of AIF-OSCORE-GROUPCOMM
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In Section 3 of version -16, point to RFC 9237 in the CDDL definition of the AIF-OSCORE-GROUPCOMM data model.

OLD
```
AIF-OSCORE-GROUPCOMM = AIF-Generic<oscore-gname, oscore-gperm>

oscore-gname = tstr  ; Group name
...
```

NEW
```
;# include rfc9237

AIF-OSCORE-GROUPCOMM = AIF-Generic<oscore-gname, oscore-gperm>

oscore-gname = tstr  ; Group name
...
```

issues.title: Clarifications about some parameters of the Join Response
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
The text in Section 6.3 "Send the Join Response" of version -16 says:

> * The 'exp' parameter MUST be present.

Considering the additions of the 'exi' parameter in draft-ietf-key-groupcomm-18 and the rules for its inclusion, the new text can instead be:

> * The 'exi' parameter MUST be present.

This means that:

* It is possible to have a Group Manager that does not support UTC time (although it's unlikely for the Group Manager to not have such support)

* Clients that do no support UTC time are surely supported by this application profile, as they can always rely on the indication from the 'exi' parameter

* The inclusion of the 'exp' parameter is still based on the normative SHOULD in Section 4.3.1 draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm , which would silently be inherited in this document.


Also, about the 'peer_identifiers' parameter, the text now says:

> The 'peer_identifiers' parameter includes ...

It should more precisely say:

> The 'peer_identifiers' parameter, if present, includes ...

In fact, this parameter is present if and only if the parameter 'creds' is also present (and there are cases where it is not, as defined in draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm).

issues.title: GET to ace-group/GROUPNAME/kdc-cred only for group members
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Due to the addition of a FETCH handler for ace-group/GROUPNAME/kdc-cred as intended to the external signature verifier (see issue #70), the use of the GET handler for this resource becomes limited to the group members only.

This means:

* Revising Section 9.5 "Retrieve the Group Manager's Authentication Credential"

* Revising the row about ace-group/GROUPNAME/kdc-cred in the table of Figure 2 "Admitted CoAP Methods on the Group Manager Resources"

* Ensuring consistency with the related changes made to address issue #70

issues.title: Consistent use of the 'exi' ACE Groupcomm Parameter
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Overall, the 'exp' parameter can silently inherit the same rules specified in draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm for its inclusion in messages.

Thinking of the worst case where a Client does not support UTC time, the parameter to privilege should instead be 'exi'.

This means, among other things:

* In Section 6.3 "Send the Join Response"

   OLD
   > * The 'exp' parameter MUST be present.

   NEW
   > * The 'exi' parameter MUST be present.


* Section 9.1 "Retrieve Updated Keying Material"

   OLD
   > ... or when the Security Context expires as specified by the 'exp' parameter of the Join Response.

   NEW
   > ... or when the Security Context expires as specified by the 'exp' or 'exi' parameter of the Join Response.


* In Section 9.1.1 "Get Group Keying Material"

   OLD
   > * The 'exp' parameter MUST be present.

   NEW
   > * The 'exp' parameter SHOULD be present.
   >
   > * The 'exi' parameter MUST be present.


* In Section 9.1.2 "Get Group Keying Material and OSCORE Sender ID"

   OLD
   > * The 'exp' parameter MUST be present.

   NEW
   > * The 'exp' parameter SHOULD be present.
   >
   > * The 'exi' parameter MUST be present.


* In Section 9.6 "Retrieve Signature Verification Data"

   OLD
   > From the Join Response message, only the parameters 'gkty', 'key', 'num', 'exp' and 'ace_groupcomm_profile' are present.

   NEW
   > Of the parameters present in the Join Response message, only the parameters 'gkty', 'key', 'num', 'exp', 'exi', and 'ace_groupcomm_profile' are present in Signature Verification Data Response.

   (then accordingly revise the example in Figure 4)


* In Section 11.1 "Sending Rekeying Messages"

   OLD
   > From the Join Response, only the parameters 'gkty', 'key', 'num', 'exp', and 'ace_groupcomm_profile' are present.

   NEW
   > Of the parameters present in the Join Response message, only the parameters 'gkty', 'key', 'num', 'exp', 'exi', and 'ace_groupcomm_profile' are present.

issues.title: Use Problem Details (RFC 9290) in error responses
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body: Consistent with what was introduced in draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm-18, use Problem Details (RFC 9290) for error responses that specify an ACE Groupcomm Error in their payload.

issues.title: CBOR integer abbreviations for ACE Groupcomm Parameters
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In Section 16.3 "ACE Groupcomm Parameters", add integer values for the "CBOR Key" fields of the registered ACE Groupcomm Parameters.

Following-up on the values given for the parameters already in draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm-18, the additional parameters in this document can take the following integer abbreviations:

* 'group_senderId' -> 21

* 'ecdh_info' -> 31

* 'kdc_dh_creds' -> 32

* 'group_enc_key' -> 33

   (to be renamed 'sign_enc_key')

* 'stale_node_ids' -> 34

issues.title: Update formulation of REQ10
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Consistently with draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm-18, REQ10 in Appendix A.1 should be updated as follows:

OLD
> REQ10 - Register a Resource Type for the root url-path, which is used to discover the correct url to access at the KDC (see Section 4.1 of [I-D.ietf-ace-key-groupcomm]): the Resource Type (rt=) Link Target Attribute value "core.osc.gm" is registered in Section 16.11.

NEW
> REQ10 - Register a Resource Type for the group-membership resource, which is used to discover the correct URL for sending a Join Request to the KDC: the Resource Type (rt=) Link Target Attribute value "core.osc.gm" is registered in Section 16.11.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Obsoleted by https://github.com/ace-wg/ace-key-groupcomm-oscore/issues/84

issues.title: Update formulation of REQ17
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Consistently with draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm-18, REQ17 in Appendix A.1 should be updated as follows:

OLD
> REQ17 - Specify the format of the 'key' parameter: see Section 6.3.

NEW
> REQ17 - Specify the format of the 'key' parameter and register a corresponding entry in the "ACE Groupcomm Key Types" IANA registry": see Section 6.3 and Section 16.4.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Obsoleted by https://github.com/ace-wg/ace-key-groupcomm-oscore/issues/84

issues.title: Update formulation of REQ21
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Consistently with draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm-18, REQ21 in Appendix A.1 should be updated as follows:

OLD
> REQ21 - Specify the approaches used to compute and verify the PoP evidence to include in 'kdc_cred_verify', and which of those approaches is used in which case: see Section 6.3, Section 6.4 and Section 9.5.

NEW
> REQ21 - Specify the approaches used to compute and verify the PoP evidence to include in 'kdc_cred_verify', and which of those approaches is used in which case. If external signature verifiers are supported, specify how those provide a nonce to the KDC to be used for computing the PoP evidence: see Section 6.3, Section 6.4 and Section 9.5.

(Section 9.5 will be seamlessly extended to describe the use of the new FETCH handler intended for external signature verifiers, which can provide a client-side nonce to use as part of the PoP input)

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Obsoleted by https://github.com/ace-wg/ace-key-groupcomm-oscore/issues/84

issues.title: Update formulation of REQ22
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Consistently with draft-ietf-ace-key-groupcomm-18, REQ22 in Appendix A.1 should be updated as follows:

OLD
> REQ22 - Specify the communication protocol that the members of the group must use: CoAP [RFC7252], also for group communication [I-D.ietf-core-groupcomm-bis].

NEW
> REQ22 - Specify the communication protocol that the members of the group must use (e.g., CoAP for group communication): CoAP [RFC7252], also for group communication [I-D.ietf-core-groupcomm-bis].

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Obsoleted by https://github.com/ace-wg/ace-key-groupcomm-oscore/issues/84

No available node identifiers

NEW (2 instances)

issues.title: Align requirements in Appendix A with RFC 9594
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics

issues.title: Add high-level recap of the concept of "scope"
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
This is about adding a new paragraph at the beginning of  Section 3 "Format of Scope", like requested for draft-ietf-ace-oscore-gm-admin during its WG Last Call.

The text below is used in Section 3 "Format of Scope" of draft-ietf-ace-oscore-gm-admin.

> Building on the definition in {{Section 3.3 of RFC6749}} considered in the ACE framework {{RFC9200}}, scope denotes: the permissions that the Client (i.e., the Administrator) seeks to obtain from the AS for accessing resources at a Resource Server (i.e., the Group Manager); and the permissions that the AS actually issues to the Client following its request. This process is detailed in {{Sections 5.8.1 and 5.8.2 of RFC9200}}.

issues.title: Use e'' in the examples in CBOR diagnostic notation
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Avoid text strings as placeholders for to-be-registered integer abbreviations.

Instead, use what is proposed in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-cbor-edn-e-ref/

issues.title: Section 5.3.1 - General definition of ecdh_info
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Section 5.3.1 should give a general definition of ecdh_info for a KDC, like the one for sign_info in RFC 9594.

In that CDDL definition, it has to be possible for cred_fmt to also be `null` (0xf6), in case the KDC does not act as repository of authentication credentials for the group members.

To that end, Section 5.3.0 has to detail how this application profile uses ecdh_info. In particular, this OSCORE Group Manager always acts as repository of the authentication credentials of group members. Therefore, in each ecdh_info_entry, cred_fmt cannot be `null` (0xf6).

issues.title: Section 5.3.2 - General definition of kdc_dh_creds
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Section 5.3.2 should give a general definition of kdc_dh_creds for a KDC, like the one for sign_info in RFC 9594.

Section 5.3.0 has to detail how this application profile uses kdc_dh_creds.

issues.title: Skip verication of PoP evidence if PoP was already achieved
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics

comments.body: "endpoint" and "resource" mixes up 2 terminology (CoAP and ACE), to refer to the same thing... how is the resource different from the endpoint?
I'm all for deleting this figure.
may signal -> MAY signal
"a joining node must have": either replace with "MUST have" or "uses"
The AS may -> The AS MAY
Remind me where this comes from?

general comment (not to fix for this submisson, obviously) for this and following sections: this is maybe too much detail, for things that are already defined in ace-key-groupcomm. We should try to avoid repetition, which makes the document hard to read. What are the things that are not described in ace-key-groupcomm?
That is exactly what I meant with "as little repetition as possible" :) This looks great
Add a reference to 'clientId' IANA section?
may request to -> may request the
"The leaving node must not" -> "is not"
Why not "Group_OSCORE_Security_Context" as name
what does it mean for a group to be "active"?

> associated to the requesting client

Do we say somewhere that the association token - sec ctx is stored? I can only find at line 493:

> The Group Manager stores the association between i) the public key of the joining node; and ii) the Group Identifier (Gid), i.e. the OSCORE ID Context, associated to the OSCORE group together with the OSCORE Sender ID assigned to the joining node in the group. The Group Manager MUST keep this association updated over time.

But that's not enough
We need to say in which condition it will not contain the rsnonce parameter (why SHOULD)
I don't remember this, when does this happen? (by the way changed to 4.00 as 4.06 is not right)
I don't understand what this sentence adds.
I would change this to it is RECOMMENDED
now fixed.
solved in ace key groupcomm
See https://github.com/ace-wg/ace-key-groupcomm/issues/60 for some situation where rsnonce can not be sent.
depending on policies
moved
kept MUST because of history
